EXCHANGE OF LETTERS BETWEEN THE PRIME MINISTER OF
SINGAPORE AND THE PRIME MINISTER OF THE FEDERATION
OF MALAYA
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


2.32 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, last week the Barisan Sosialis in Singapore issued a statement in which they violently attacked the Federation Government for the proposed amendments to the Federation Constitution now before the Federation Parliament. The Federation Government can and doubtless will in due course take care of such violent attacks themselves. But in the course of the statement, the Barisan Sosialis made a wild allegation that the purpose of one of the amendments was to facilitate removal of the reserve powers of the Singapore State Government, with particular reference to reserve State powers in education and labour.

    In their campaign to create confusion among the people over their constitutional position after merger, they have

Column: 224

recklessly first demanded merger as a 12th State like Penang arid offered to surrender education and labour to the Central Government. Now, on realising that the people wish education and labour to be reserve powers of the State, they are taking the contradictory line that these reserve powers, though valuable, will not be left alone.

    I now publish for information of Members an exchange of letters between myself and the Prime Minister of the Federation of Malaya. These letters were exchanged at the time prior to the publication of the White Paper on 11th November, 1961. In my letter, I wrote:

TEXT OF THE LETTER FROM THE PRIME MINISTER, MR LEE KUAN YEW, TO THE FEDERATION'S PRIME MINISTER, TUNKU ABDUL RAHMAN PUTRA AL-HAJ. DATED NOVEMBER 11, 1961 
          



       `My dear Prime Minister,



            You will be leaving for London on 16th November, 

          1961, for  discussions with the Prime Minister  of

          the  United Kingdom on your far-reaching proposals

          for  the  creation of the Federation  of  Malaysia

          comprising  the  eleven  States  of  the   present

          Federation of Malaya, the States of Singapore  and

          Brunei  and the territories of Sarawak  and  North

          Borneo.  You  carry with you the  support  of  the

          people  of  the Federation of Malaya and  also  of

          Singapore.  We in Singapore have always recognised

          that  the  destiny of Singapore lies in  a  merger

          with the Federation of Malaya.

          

            I  am happy that we have reached agreement on the

          constitutional framework between Singapore and the

          present Federation of Malaya in the new Federation

          of Malaysia.

          

            I  shall  be  publishing as  a  White  Paper  the

          memorandum which you and I have agreed upon. May I

          record  your assurance to me that these  heads  of

          agreement  will be  amended only after  preliminary

          consultations between us, and only after agreement

          would  the  matter  he referred  for  approval  of

          Parliament by the majority of members.



            When  you set out in your last mission to  London

          in  January 1956 you brought hack Merdeka  to  the

          Federation  of  Malaya,  and  with  it  peace  and

          prosperity  for  the  people.  May  your   present

          mission  bring stability, prosperity and happiness

          for all the people of Malaysia.

 

                                          Yours sincerely,

                                       Signed: Lee Kuan Yew.'


Column: 225



    In his reply of the same date (11th November, 1961), the Prime Minister of the Federation wrote as follows:

TEXT OF REPLY FROM THE FEDERATION'S PRIME MINISTER, TUNKU ABDUL RAHMAN PUTRA AL-HAJ, TO THE PRIME MINISTER, MR LEE KUAN YEW, DATED NOVEMBER 11, 1961 

        `My dear Prime Minister,



            Thank  you very much for your letter of the 11th

          November, 1961, in which you conveyed the  support

          and  good  wishes of the Government and people  of

          Singapore   for  the  success  of  my  forthcoming

          discussions  in London with the Prime Minister  of

          Britain.



            With  regard to the memorandum which you propose

          to  publish as a White Paper, I am to confirm that

          the heads of agreement including State and Federal

          responsibilities  should  serve   as   the   basic

          proposals  for  merger and  the  extent  of  local

          autonomy to be retained by Singapore.



            Of  course  in  the  light of experience certain

          amendments,    modifications,   alterations    and

          revocations  may  have to be made  in  respect  of

          those  proposals, in particular  the  Federal  and

          State  responsibilities. However, when such action

          is contemplated  there   should   be   preliminary

          consultations between us and only after  agreement

          would  the  matter  be referred  for  approval  of

          Parliament by the majority of members.



            May  I wish you and your colleagues all the best

          in  the coming Legislative Assembly when you  will

          be  launching this historic debate which no  doubt

          will  have far reaching effect for the future well

          being  and security of Singapore and Malaya  as  a

          whole.



                                      Yours sincerely,

                           Signed: Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra.'


    Sir, the letters record that the heads of agreement contained in the White Paper Cmd. 33 of 1961 spelling out the reserve powers for Singapore can be amended only after preliminary consultations between us, and only after agreement would the matter be referred for the approval of Parliament by the majority of the members there.

    In his letter confirming this, the Federation Prime Minister made reference to the fact that in the light of experience certain amendments, modification, alterations and revocations may

Column: 226

have to be made in respect of those proposals, in particular the Federal and State responsibilities.

    No modification is contemplated for education or labour. The modifications that may arise in the light of experience refer to the other subjects and responsibilities, other than education and labour, which have been entrusted in the heads of agreement reached between the Singapore and the Federation Governments.

    By way of example, the working Party has now reached agreement with the approval of both Governments that shipping should be placed on the concurrent list, but that fisheries, which was a pan-Malayan department before the war, should be placed on the Federal list. These two subjects were left out of the Schedule published in Command Paper 33 of 1961 as there was then still discussion as to the ultimate division of responsibility in these two subjects.

    If and when alteration is contemplated, there will be prior consultation and prior agreement.

    Further, at the meeting of the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee in Kuala Lumpur 10 days ago, the Minister for Health and Social Welfare of the Federation of Malaya, as leader of the Federation delegation, agreed in reply to questions submitted by delegates from North Borneo and Sarawak that constitutional safeguards were desirable and that an individual State which is given autonomy in respect of a particular subject not conceded as a State subject in the other States in the present Federation can have constitutional safeguards to be worked out by constitutional experts.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I have put in copies of the exchange of letters for the information of Members.

    Copies of the letters handed in to the Clerk.

    Mr Speaker: That statement, of course, is open to question, if any. No questions? The Clerk will now proceed to read the Orders of the Day.

MERGER AND CONSTITUTIONAL FUTURE (SINGAPORE)


2.41 p.m.

    Order read for resumption of motion,

    `That this Assembly views with grave concern and anxiety the exclusion of the Opposition Parties in the current "merger" negotiations, and demands that the Government convene forthwith an All-Party Conference to discuss and to agree on all basic questions on the constitutional future of Singapore; and failing agreement, demands that the Government seek without delay a new mandate from the people.' -(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the House rose yesterday, I was briefly touching on the shameful record of the P.A.P. in the merger negotiations. I showed the House that the letter from the Deputy Prime Minister, the Acting Prime Minister at that time, to the Opposition leaders on the 1st September, 1961, was a cheap political propaganda stunt calculated to deceive the people that all Parties had been consulted in their sell-out merger. I was saying. Sir, that even the reactionary Lim Yew Hock Government had the decency to consult all the Parties and had agreement with them in principle before proceeding to negotiate with the British Government in 1958.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): So you prefer the Lim Yew Heck Government.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: But now, the Lee Kuan Yew Government must make it a one-Party affair.

    An hon. Member: Petir.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, in view of all this, we then urged the Acting Prime Minister at that time to place the matter before the people. The Workers' Party and the United People's Party both supported our stand. The Workers' Party implored the Government to call the House into session forthwith. The United People's Party asked for the convening of an All-Party conference without delay. I listed six instances yesterday with dates, Sir. Now I come to the seventh.

    (7) The next chapter (this is the seventh) of this shameful record of dictatorial rule opened on the 6th of

Column: 228

September, 1961, when the Acting Prime Minister said, "If an All-Party conference is to be of value to assist and guide the Government in its deliberations on the constitutional arrangement for merger, there must be unanimity on the main points."

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Correct.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, simple logic tells us that you cannot know if there is agreement or no agreement unless and until there is a coming together for at: exchange of views. In this case there was never consultation of the views of the Opposition Parties at any stage of the negotiations to date. So it is nonsense for the Deputy Prime Minister to presume there was no unanimity on the main points. Whether we agree or not is another matter. What concerns us at the moment is that there is arbitrary and dictatorial action on the part of the P.A.P. Government.

    (8) On the 16th of September, 1961, the second joint statement of the two Prime Ministers was issued and on the following day, a further confusing Press interview was given by the Prime Minister of Singapore. But this is the point: of official news from the Government to the Opposition Parties, there was nothing. Even the Member for Farrer Park complained in the radio forum of 21st September, 1961, when the question of an All-Party Conference was discussed.

    The Prime Minister: One forum you will not forget for a long, long time.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The Minister for Finance was told in no uncertain terms that the P.A.P. should not treat everybody as fools.

    (9) On 12th October, 1961, the Member for Tanglin after much serious thinking also came out with a call for an All-Party Conference of political Parties in the Assembly.

    (10) Following this, on 6th October, 1961, three Opposition leaders the Member for Hong Lim on behalf of the United People's Party, the Member for Anson on behalf of the Workers' Party -

Column: 229



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: A one-man Party.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - and myself on behalf of the Barisan Sosialis jointly sent a letter to the Leader of the House urging the Government to convene a meeting of the Assembly forthwith to consider and debate the basic principles and to appoint an All-Party Conference.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: For what reason?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: But what did the D.P.M. say?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: But what did the who say?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the Leader of the House knows the rules of debate. If he wishes for clarification, he should please stand up and he will get clarification. I cannot allow this running commentary from the ministerial Benches.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Anyway, he said that there was no necessity and that it was all plain nonsense.

    Sir, from all this, it is apparent that the Opposition Parties have been deliberately denied the right to participate in charting the course of our own constitutional future. We do not seek the right solely to decide Singapore's constitutional future. All we ask is the right of participation. Notwithstanding this, the P.A.P. has seen fit solely to decide on the constitutional future of Singapore. It is now quite clear to the people of Singapore that the P.A.P. has committed the whole future of Singapore over the question of its phoney merger because the P.A.P. is an active sponsor of the Malaysia scheme. Malaysia is the only political objective of the Tunku. He has made it quite clear that there is going to be no acceptance of Singapore if there is no Malaysia - a very consistent stand of the Tunku. Singapore therefore is only wanted for the sole purpose of Malaysia.

    Sir, as political events unfold themselves, the people of Singapore are becoming increasingly confused and confounded.

Column: 230



    The Prime Minister: You are.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Today the people find themselves in an extremely extraordinary situation. They feel that their future is being decided step by step by the Tunku, the Prime Minister of the Federation. First, when he made a lengthy speech during the October session of the Federal Parliament last year. Then again when he addressed the U.M.N.O. delegates at a meeting in Kuala Lumpur on 4th November. And again when he flew to London in mid-November 1961 for exploratory Malaysia talks. I mention this, Sir, because there is a very widespread impression that the British position in Singapore will be replaced by the Federation Government and that that is going to be the constitutional future of Singapore whether we like it or not. Sir, this impression regarding -

    The Prime Minister: Sir, on a point of information.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, this impression -

    Mr Speaker: Order, Is the Member giving way?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: No, Sir. This impression regarding the transfer of power has spread as far as all the Borneo territories. It would be reasonable to expect that if our constitutional future is going to be tied up with the Malaysia scheme and not just a question of merger with the Federation in isolation, there would have been at least an All-Party Conference to discuss the various implications of this scheme from the point of view of Singapore in accordance with past practice in 1956 and 1958. But no. All we know was a statement of support for Malaysia by the Secretary-General of the P.A.P. And then, of course, we learned of the formation of the Malaysia Solidarity Consultative Committee at its first meeting in Jesselton on 24th August, 1961, which was supposed to have been a meeting held at C.P.A. level. You will remember, Sir, that I wrote to ask if you, as the President of the C.P.A., knew anything about it and your answer that your knowledge of the matter was

Column: 231

as gathered from the newspapers is sufficient testimony of the dictatorial rule of the P.A.P. Government. One would have thought that the P.A.P. would have had the good sense to hold an All-Party Conference to decide on the stand that Singapore should adopt at this Conference and to agree upon a truly representative delegation so that the true voice of Singapore could be heard. But again no. The P.A.P. did not hold an All-Party Conference, nor was Singapore represented by a truly representative delegation at this forum. It was only after criticism was directed against the P.A.P. and after you, Sir, had insisted on representation from the Barisan Sosialis -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the Member for Queenstown has got it wrong. It was no question of insisting. It was a question of a conference or discussion and in any event that discussion took place in a Committee meeting of the C.P.A. and should never be made public except by consent of the Executive Committee.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I will not mention that episode, Sir.

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Apologise.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Anyway, it was only after criticism was directed against the P.A.P. that a Member of the Barisan Sosialis was included among the Singapore delegates to Kuching recently and to Kuala Lumpur too.

    The Prime Minister: If we had taken him to Jesselton, no progress would have been made.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The tragedy of the situation is that the P.A.P. believes that the future of Singapore should lie in the fruition of the Malaysia scheme and its phoney plan, and because of this -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I have been listening to this description of the proposed merger which is being referred to as a phoney merger. Does that expression mean the terms of agreement as

Column: 232

contained in Cmd. Paper No. 33 of 1961 which was debated in this House?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I mean that one, Sir, but if -

    Mr Speaker: Then I must remind the hon. Member that that Paper has been accepted by this House and, therefore, to describe that Paper as phoney is a reflection on this House. Therefore, no such epithet should be used in connection with that Paper.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Because of this, the P.A.P. -

    The Prime Minister: Because of what?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - has without hesitation proceeded to commit the whole of Singapore accordingly. Its basic assumption is that in the whole of Singapore the P.A.P. and the P.A.P. alone knows what is best for Singapore. The P.A.P. leadership believes that the people of Singapore should not even query the P.A.P.'s decision about their own future, How can the P.A.P. say that the people will be given an opportunity to decide when the P.A.P. has already decided for us?

    Sir, in view of all this, I have no doubt that history will record this phase of our political development -

    The Prime Minister: As a folly of the Barisan Sosialis.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Sell-out.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - as a chapter of autocracy in pseudo-democracy.

    Sir, the people know only one road of constitutional advance, and that is that the future of Singapore should be planned and decided by the people of Singapore themselves and not by one political Party in conjunction with people outside Singapore.

    Sir, at the last sitting, as you have reminded me, Cmd. Paper No. 33 of 1961 was adopted by the Legislative Assembly. There was no difficulty in getting the Assembly to pass those merger (in inverted commas) proposals of the P.A.P. -

Column: 233



    Mr Speaker: Order. Even the inverted commas have an innuendo and must not be used. These are merger proposals vvhich have been accepted by the Assembly and must be referred to as such.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - as the P.A.P. is now hand in glove with the S.P.A. and has the help of seven or eight, extra votes. We in the Barisan Sosialis, and I hope other Opposition Parties as well, have unequivocally rejected the White Paper. But if the P.A.P. respects democracy, then let us come together on an All-Party Conference now [Laughter]. The P.A.P. laughs. It never had any mandate from the people on such Malaysia proposals.

    An hon. Member: Have you got one?

    Mr Speaker: Order. I do not understand why there is this running com-me'ntary from the opposite Benches [Interruption] Order. When the Speaker is speaking, there must be silence. I would suggest that the Member for Queenstown be given an opportunity of making his speech without unseemly interruptions.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Thank you, Sir, I would ask the P.A.P. that we should now try and seek an agreement on the constitutional advance of Singapore on a different and an entirely new basis from the White Paper, Paper Cmd. 33. If this conference fails to produce a common agreement, then there should be general elections to resolve this problem.

    Now, Sir, the Prime Minister laughs, and the P.A.P. has said that a general election is not the way to resolve this problem because the voters, according to the Prime Minister, will be further confused by the multitude of election programmes and party stands on Singapore's constitutional future. The P.A.P. says so, of course, simply because it is not confident of its stand and its pro-gramme being adopted by the majority of the voters. We in the Barisan Sosialis are not afraid of the voters. We are confident the

Column: 234

voters will not be confused by the multitude of election programmes and party stands. We are confident the voters will know what programme and what party stand to reject. We are confident the voters will know what programme and what party stand to accept. We trust the wisdom of the people and we feel sure the P.A.P. will be trounced good and proper in a general election now. Whichever Party that comes into power after a general election should be in a better position to plan and decide the constitutional advance for Singapore in a truly democratic way through consultation by way of an All-Party conference and in close consultation with the people.

    Sir, I beg to move,

    That this Assembly views with grave concern and anxiety the exclusion of the Oppo-sition Parties in the current 'merger' negotiations, and demands that the Government convene forthwith an All-Party Conference to discuss and to agree on all basic questions on the constitutional future of Singapore; and failing agreement, demands that the Govern-ment seek without delay a new mandate from the people.

    Question proposed.

3.05 p.m.

    Mr Low Por Tuck (Havelock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to second the motion.

    Mr Speaker: Order. There is no necessity to second the motion.

    Mr Low Por Tuck: Thank you, Sir. Mr, Speaker, Sir, though the P.A.P. has gone so far in its secretive manoeuvring to push through its phoney merger plans -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I must remind the Member for Havelock that I have over-ruled that type of expression in connection with this merger plan which has been accepted by the Assembly. If he has a prepared script, I suggest that he cancel the word "phoney".

    Mr Low Por Tuck: Mr Speaker, Sir, though the P.A.P. has secretly manoeuvred in pushing through its merger plans and cannot retreat now witho'ut losing face with the Tunku, we are nevertheless insisting on calling for an All-Party conference to discuss this

Column: 235

extremely important national issue of merger. The P.A.P. which professes to believe in democracy has unfortunately set a very bad example by the way it has carried through the so-called merger negotiations.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not intend to repeat what my Party Chairman, the Member for Queenstown, has said, but I wish to emphasise that for the P.A.P. to treat a national issue as a private party affair is, to say the least, extremely regrettable. Our people have seen the successful functions of All-Party delegations in the past in advancing the constitutional status of Singapore. What we have been seeking so far is that the Parties should first get together to decide on certain basic principles and then to proceed as a united body to negotiate for our constitutional advancement. The P.A.P. unfortunately has done things in exactly the opposite manner. Firstly, it wants to negotiate secretly with the Federation Government and, after reaching agreement on so-called principles, then make a pretence of consulting with the other Parties. What sort of consultation is this when we are told of arrangements after they have already been agreed upon by the Governments of the two territories? The P.A.P. is now treating the merger question as a way out to salvage its own political future. It has a vast interest, so to speak, to see that some kind of political link-up be brought about as soon as possible before the deadline of 1964 when it has to face the people again. The P.A.P. is now hoping, as has been pointed out before, that such arrangements will allow the Federation Government to purge its political opponents before the next general elections.

    Sir, perhaps it is useless to appeal to the P.A.P. to refrain from going on in this secretive manner in dealing with a national problem. We know that with the meagre one-man majority in this House, the P.A.P. can do anything it wants. But that does not mean that it is morally justified in conducting the affairs of our people in this manner.

Column: 236

The P.A.P. leaders have repeatedly declared before 'that they would not govern without the moral support of the people. Can they say that they now have the moral support of the people? An All-Party conference would have given full expression to the various opinions on the question of merger. If the P.A.P. leaders believe that by pushing through this merger scheme they can save their own political future, then they are going to be sadly mistaken. The real way to stay in power is to go with the people and heed their views and aspirations.

    Sir, it is utterly nonsensical for the P.A.P. to suggest that the people will be confused during a general election. The Prime Minister has said that there will be dozens of political Parties with hundreds of candidates at a general election and the people will all be confused. But, Sir, during the last general election, there were 11 political Parties and about 200 candidates contesting for the people's votes. Were our people confused? Were they confused by the various parties and dubious characters springing up on the eve of the general electioo? No. Sir,Instead of being confused, they made a clear-cut decision. The P.A.P. was returned with an overwhelming majority. And we who have been in the P.A.P. know that the people voted the Party to power because of its uncompromising stand against colonialism. The people were then utterly fed up with the previous Government which had conspired with the colonial and reactionary elements to bring widespread repression and suffering to the people of Singapore. The people in 1959, Sir, looked towards the P.A.P. in the hope and expectation that they would get rid of, once and for all, the oppression and repression they had suffered at the hands of the Lim Yew Hock Government. But now they see that this P.A.P. Government, on whom they have placed the trust, are trying its level best to juggle with and manipulate the constitutional future of our people in such a manner that will result in a return of the dark days of the Lim Yew Hock Government.

Column: 237



    Sir, let the P.A.P. leaders not think that they can escape responsibility for the oppression and suffering of the workers of Singapore that will follow the merger scheme. Let them not think that just because it will be the Federation Government that will be doing the dirty work, they will escape responsibility. Those who conspire with and make it possible for others to carry out repression of our people will themselves be equally responsible for these acts of repressions. The people are not fools who cannot see through this intricate conspiracy between the P.A.P. and the the reactionary elements in the Federation.

    Sir, it is ridiculous for the P.A.P. to say that just because it has merger as one of its many election platforms, it therefore has the people's mandate to bring abo'ut any sort of political link-up with the Federation. For that matter ,merger was on the platform of practically every political Party at that time. The people want to be merged with the Federation but with equality, mutual respect, and mutual benefit, not this present completely one-sided arrangement. The people want to be married with the Federation, and not to be taken in as a mistress.
